ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained insight into hot topics in space governance like debris and militarization, and learned about international law, IP law, torts, international investment law, and more.
Knowledge of International Law, Maritime Law, Space Policy, interactions between current events and domestic and international politics

Firm grasp on the state of international space law and the opportunities/challenges that lie ahead; additionally, learned more about how "international law" functions, particular technological/geopolitical situations relating to outer space, etc.
Broader understanding of the delicate balance of international law especially in the emerging uncharted territory of space governance
Frameworks to understand international law which is very different from domestic law. Using research from limited but expanding research centers on this new field of law.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: At the beginning of this course, the background on international law was a little theoretical and might have turned off prospective students who felt a little lost. However, as the semester progressed and we began discussing specific issues and hypothetical scenarios, everything started to come together. Dr. Hasin also designed the course very well--the readings provided excellent background and seemed to build off of each other. There was also a good mix of news stories and legal scholarship. He also created a relaxing environment of free-flowing discussions, and was kind in the flexibility he provided for the 3 memos and final paper. Indeed, I thought that these assignments were very educational and relatively stress-free, which is exactly what assessments should be like.

Strengths: knowledgeable professor and great collection of readings/literature; fascinating area of study.

Weaknesses: minimal feedback received on assignments; seminars would too often go on tangents unrelated to daily topics + eventually, entire schedule ended up being shifted back one class (would've benefited from more instructor-led focusing).

Class would be better with more people. We only had ~8 students. 
It would be more interesting if we talked more about actual policies. This class was a bit too high-level. 
Guest lectures were great, we should have more.

Discussions were usually pretty interesting, but it was not uncommon for Gershon to lapse into lecturing. Consider more questions and how to ask questions such that it promotes more discussion among students.

Strengths - huge expertise of instructor and ability to share anecdotes. Weaknesses - Difficult to carry on concepts from previous class since only met once a week, so a quick chalkboard review would be useful each session; more writing on the board in general.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For students who are willing to engage with legal concepts that are not always the most straightforward, yes. Dr. Hasin is extremely knowledgeable and kind, and the syllabus provided a deep and broad introduction to key issues in space governance.
Yes! It's a fascinating, emerging field of study that every student would benefit from learning more about.
Yes, if there are more people in the class.

Yes - even if you have limited legal understanding this taught you a lot about what the future holds in terms of policy challenges. In life, you will be faced with similarly ambiguous challenges, so this course helped you learn how to find all the answers/possibilities out there thus far.
